dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A seventy-two percent drop in the S&P 500? That just sounds… completely unbelievable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A seventy-two percent drop in the S&P five hundred? That just sounds... completely unbelievable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The stock markets explosive growth this yearthe S&P has risen more than 27%means that 2019 is shaping up to be one of the best years for investing in recent history, which has been a boon for the leading tech giants that have seen their market caps grow rapidly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it sounds wild, but the numbers are there—Apple's market cap fell to just $1.1 billion. That's a collapse of nearly $700 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it sounds wild, but the numbers are there-Apple's market cap fell to just one point one dollars billion. That's a collapse of nearly seven hundred dollars billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple stock had a blockbuster year in which its market value rose by $497 billion to nearly $1.25 trillion, as its stock hit numerous new record highs in the second half of 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But come on, Apple? Dropping that low? Their brand alone should cushion some of that fall, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But come on, Apple? Dropping that low? Their brand alone should cushion some of that fall, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: You'd think so, but apparently Apple TV+ was a total flop, and sales just cratered. It wasn't just them—Google lost over $800 billion too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You'd think so, but apparently Apple T V+ was a total flop, and sales just cratered. It wasn't just them-Google lost over eight hundred dollars billion too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company benefited from strong product sales and its entry into the streaming wars with Apple TV+. Google, which still dominates in digital advertising and searchthough its also expanding into areas like artificial intelligence and self-driving carshas seen its market cap go up by $214 billion to almost $934 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but what about the gainers? Like, DuPont's market cap jumped over 200%? How does a chemical company surge like that in a crash?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but what about the gainers? Like, DuPont's market cap jumped over two hundred percent? How does a chemical company surge like that in a crash?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: DuPont, previously the worlds largest chemical conglomerate, spun off numerous businesses throughout the year, including its commodity chemical subsidiary Dow and agricultural unit Corteva, which slashed the companys market cap by more than half in April. Its market value has fallen nearly $34 billion over the course of the year, down to a total of $47.5 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they launched new commodity chemical divisions—Dow and Corteva—and Wall Street loved it. Their value went up almost $74 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they launched new commodity chemical divisions-Dow and Corteva-and Wall Street loved it. Their value went up almost seventy four dollars billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: DuPont, previously the worlds largest chemical conglomerate, spun off numerous businesses throughout the year, including its commodity chemical subsidiary Dow and agricultural unit Corteva, which slashed the companys market cap by more than half in April. Its market value has fallen nearly $34 billion over the course of the year, down to a total of $47.5 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Pfizer? Up $133 billion because of one drug? That seems… uh, almost too convenient for a year this bad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Pfizer? Up one hundred thirty three dollars billion because of one drug? That seems... uh, almost too convenient for a year this bad.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pfizer saw its market value fall just over $33 billionto $218 billionin 2019.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it was a blockbuster drug, plus they merged their generic division—Upjohn. Analysts went nuts for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it was a blockbuster drug, plus they merged their generic division-Upjohn. Analysts went nuts for it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats due to declining sales and the merger of its Upjohn generic drugs division with Mylan earlier in the year, which generated a negative reaction from Wall Street analysts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, losing trillions in tech while old-school companies like Kraft Heinz gain billions? It feels like a bizarro market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, losing trillions in tech while old-school companies like Kraft Heinz gain billions? It feels like a bizarro market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz, one of billionaire investor Warren Buffetts biggest holdings (almost a 27% stake), saw its stock fall more than 30% in late February after the company wrote down the value of iconic brands Kraft and Oscar Mayer by more than $15 billion. Shares havent really recovered since, and the company lost $13.5 billion in market value this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Warren Buffett's stake in Kraft Heinz paid off big—their stock rose 60% after some new product launches.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Warren Buffett's stake in Kraft Heinz paid off big-their stock rose sixty percent after some new product launches.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kraft Heinz, one of billionaire investor Warren Buffetts biggest holdings (almost a 27% stake), saw its stock fall more than 30% in late February after the company wrote down the value of iconic brands Kraft and Oscar Mayer by more than $15 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But hold on—this data is from a "fictitious source." Should we even be taking these numbers seriously?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But hold on-this data is from a fictitious source. Should we even be taking these numbers seriously?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Market cap data sourced from YCharts, as of December 20, 2019. Forbes.com

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, the trends might be exaggerated, but the idea that pharma and consumer goods thrived while tech imploded? That part feels plausible, given how volatile markets can be.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, the trends might be exaggerated, but the idea that pharma and consumer goods thrived while tech imploded? That part feels plausible, given how volatile markets can be.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the boom times have also left some competitors behind, among them some of the countrys biggest pharmaceutical, chemical, and consumer goods companies, reflecting changing times.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I guess when people panic, they flock to staples—medicine, groceries, things that feel safe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I guess when people panic, they flock to staples-medicine, groceries, things that feel safe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Walgreens Boots Alliance jumped over $63 billion from online sales alone. It's all about shifting priorities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Walgreens Boots Alliance jumped over sixty three dollars billion from online sales alone. It's all about shifting priorities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Walgreens Boots Alliance: The international drug store chains market cap has decreased $13.1 billion this year, to $52 billion, as the company faces heightened concerns about competition from online retailers, leading it to slash costs and explore a massive potential leveraged buyout from a private company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, Amazon dropping nearly a trillion? That's just… hard to wrap my head around.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, Amazon dropping nearly a trillion? That's just... hard to wrap my head around.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon has seen its market value go up by almost $150 billionto a total of $887 billionthis year, thanks to strong growth in its cloud-computing (Amazon Web Services) and advertising businesses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, AWS and retail both collapsed according to this. Wild times.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A W S and retail both collapsed according to this. Wild times.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon has seen its market value go up by almost $150 billionto a total of $887 billionthis year, thanks to strong growth in its cloud-computing (Amazon Web Services) and advertising businesses.

artist_script:
HostA: A seventy-two percent drop in the S&P 500? That just sounds… completely unbelievable.
HostB: I know, it sounds wild, but the numbers are there—Apple’s market cap fell to just $1.1 billion. That’s a collapse of nearly $700 billion.
HostA: But come on, Apple? Dropping that low? Their brand alone should cushion some of that fall, right?
HostB: You’d think so, but apparently Apple TV+ was a total flop, and sales just cratered. It wasn’t just them—Google lost over $800 billion too.
HostA: Okay, but what about the gainers? Like, DuPont’s market cap jumped over 200%? How does a chemical company surge like that in a crash?
HostB: Yeah, they launched new commodity chemical divisions—Dow and Corteva—and Wall Street loved it. Their value went up almost $74 billion.
HostA: And Pfizer? Up $133 billion because of one drug? That seems… uh, almost too convenient for a year this bad.
HostB: Well, it was a blockbuster drug, plus they merged their generic division—Upjohn. Analysts went nuts for it.
HostA: Still, losing trillions in tech while old-school companies like Kraft Heinz gain billions? It feels like a bizarro market.
HostB: Right? Warren Buffett’s stake in Kraft Heinz paid off big—their stock rose 60% after some new product launches.
HostA: But hold on—this data is from a “fictitious source.” Should we even be taking these numbers seriously?
HostB: I mean, the trends might be exaggerated, but the idea that pharma and consumer goods thrived while tech imploded? That part feels plausible, given how volatile markets can be.
HostA: I guess when people panic, they flock to staples—medicine, groceries, things that feel safe.
HostB: Exactly. Walgreens Boots Alliance jumped over $63 billion from online sales alone. It’s all about shifting priorities.
HostA: Still, Amazon dropping nearly a trillion? That’s just… hard to wrap my head around.
HostB: Yeah, AWS and retail both collapsed according to this. Wild times.
